review.title: Big data and the SP theory of intelligence
review.abstract: This article is about how the "SP theory of intelligence", and its realisation in the "SP machine", may, with advantage, be applied to the management and analysis of big data. The SP system has potential for the discovery of 'natural' structures in big data at various levels of abstraction, including recurrent patterns and associations, and discontinuous dependencies in data. Potential applications include the discovery of recurrent patterns in economics-related data, in meteorological data, in DNA sequences and amino-acid sequences, and in associations between biochemical structures and diseases. Since information compression is at the heart of the SP system, and since the system has potential to achieve relatively high levels of compression, it may achieve useful reductions in the volume of big data and thus facilitate its storage and management. There is potential for substantial economies in the transmission of big data, and for the efficient processing of compressed data, without the need for decompression. In the interpretation of data, the SP system has capabilities that include such things as the parsing and production of language, pattern recognition, and various kinds of probabilistic reasoning. But potentially the most useful facility with big data would be scanning for patterns, with recognition of family-resemblance or polythetic categories, at multiple levels of abstraction and with part-whole hierarchies, with inductive prediction and the calculation of associated probabilities, with a role for context in recognition, and robust in the face of errors of omission, commission or substitution. There are potential applications in several areas including, security, criminal investigations, finance, meteorology, and astronomy.
histories: Accepted for publication in IEEE Access

sections.heading: III. OVERCOMING THE PROBLEM OF VARIETY IN BIG DATA
sections.text: "Manipulating and integrating heterogeneous data from different sources into a meaningful common representation is a major challenge." [1, p. 76] "Over the past decade, computer scientists and mathematicians have become quite adept at handling certain types of data using specialized tools that do a good job." [2, p. 48] "But this approach does not work for complex operational challenges such as managing cities, global supply chains, or power grids, where many interdependencies exist and many different types of data need to be taken into account." The many different types of data include: the world's many spoken or written languages; static and moving images; music as sound and music in its written form; tables; graphics; networks; grammars; computer programs; and much more.

sections.heading: B. The Potential of the SP System as a Universal Framework for the Representation and Processing of Knowledge
sections.text: Indeed, it is not as if this is a political system, but a system in which the interests of the individual are paramount.

sections.heading: C. Standardisation and Translation
sections.text: The SP system or any other UFK can be used in two different ways: • Standardization in the representation of knowledge. On relatively long time scales, there is the potential to standardize the representation and processing of many types of knowledge, eliminating much of the current confusion of formalities and formats. However, for the reasons stated in Section III, it is likely that some of these formalisms or formats will never be replaced or will coexist with the representation and processing by the UFK. • Translation into the universal framework. Where a stock of information is expressed in one or more non-standardized forms, but is needed in the standard form, it can be translated. This can be done via the SP system as described in Section V., or it can be done using conventional technologies, just as the source code for a computer program can be translated into object code using a compiler.

sections.heading: IV. LEARNING AND DISCOVERY
sections.text: "While traditional computers must be programmed by humans to perform certain tasks, cognitive systems will learn from their interaction with data and people, and in some ways be able to program themselves to perform new tasks." [2, p. 7] In broad terms, unattended learning in the SP system means the lossless compression of an information body, I, by mapping and standardizing patterns (Section IV-A). The SP computer model (SP70, [4, Chapter 9], [3, Section 5]) has already demonstrated the ability to detect generative grammars from unsegmented samples of English art languages, including segmental structures, classes of structures, and abstract patterns. In its current form, it exhibits deficiencies outlined in Section 3.3, Section 3.3]. But I believe that these problems are solvable, and that their solution will pave the way to unattended learning of other types of structures, such as hierarchies, subcontinuities and discontinuities in Section 3.3].

sections.heading: A. The Product of Learning
sections.text: The product of learning from a data body, I, can include a grammar (G) and an encoding (E) of I in relation to grammar. Here, the term "grammar" has a broad meaning, which includes grammars for natural languages, grammars for static and moving images, grammars for business processes, etc. As with all other types of data in the SP system, G and E are both represented with SP patterns. In accordance with the principles of minimal encryption, the SP system aims to minimize the overall size of G and E.5 together.

sections.text: A roadblock to using cloud services for massive data analytics is the problem of transferring large data sets. Maintaining a high-performance and wide-ranging communications network is very expensive and only marginally more profitable. To equip a conventional computer with comparable cognitive capacity would require gigawatts of electricity and a machine the size of a football field. So something has to fundamentally change when it comes to harnessing the millions of hours of video, billions of photos, and countless sensor signals that surround us.

sections.heading: A. Parsing or Pattern Recognition That Is Robust in the Face of Errors
sections.text: As mentioned in Section II, the SP system is inherently probabilistic; each SP pattern has a related frequency of occurrence, and probabilities can be derived for each multiple alignment [3, Section 4.4], [4, Section 3.7, and Chapter 7]. The probabilistic nature of the system means that it is robust in the face of errors of omission, commissioning, or substitution [3, Section 4.2.2], [4, Section 6.2.1] in operations such as analyzing natural language or pattern recognition. Just as we can visually detect things despite disturbances such as falling leaves or snow (and also for other senses), the SP system can produce within limits what we intuitively consider "correct," analyzing inputs that are not completely accurate. Figure 4 shows how the SP system can achieve a "correct" capability, as shown in Fig.

sections.heading: B. Unsupervised Learning with Errors and Uncertainties in Data
sections.text: This year, it has come to the point that it has never come as far as it has this year.

sections.heading: C. Rarity, Probabilities, and Errors
sections.text: In this context, it should be noted that the persons in question are not persons who are able to determine themselves, but persons who are able to determine themselves and persons who are able to determine themselves.

sections.heading: XII. A ROAD MAP
sections.text: As mentioned in Section II, it is envisaged that the SP computer model will form the basis for the development of a new version of the SP machine. How things can develop is schematically illustrated in Figure 6. It is envisaged that this new version will be realized as a virtual software machine hosted on an existing supercomputer, that it will have a high degree of parallelism, that it will be accessible from anywhere in the world via a user-friendly interface, that all software will be open source, and that users will be able to create new versions of the system. This highly parallel open source version of the SP machine will be a means for researchers everywhere to explore what can be done with the system and to create new versions of it. As convincingly argued in [2, chapters 5 and 6] and as reflected in this article in Sections IX-A3 and IX-B, it will probably be necessary to get a grip on the development of new architectures for processors.

sections.heading: XIII. CONCLUSION
sections.text: The SP system, designed to simplify and integrate concepts relating to artificial intelligence, mainstream computing and human perception and cognition, has potential in the management and analysis of big data. The SP system has potential as a universal framework for the representation and processing of different types of knowledge (UFK) and contributes to reducing the problem of the diversity of big data: the wide variety of formalities and formats for knowledge and its processing. The system can discover "natural" structures in big data, and it has strengths in the interpretation of data, including such things as pattern recognition, processing natural language, different types of reasoning and much more. It is suitable for the analysis of streaming data and helps to overcome the problem of speed in big data. Apart from several indirect advantages described in this article, the information compression in the SP system should bring direct benefits in the storage, management and transmission of big data by reducing it by transferring data.

sections.heading: XIV. ACKNOWLEDGEMENTS
sections.text: I am grateful to Daniel J. Wolff for drawing my attention to big data as an area where the SP system can make a contribution.

metadata.abstractText: This article is about how the SP theory of intelligence and its realisation in the SP machine may, with advantage, be applied to the management and analysis of big data. The SP system—introduced in the article and fully described elsewhere— may help to overcome the problem of variety in big data: it has potential as a universal framework for the representation and processing of diverse kinds of knowledge (UFK), helping to reduce the diversity of formalisms and formats for knowledge and the different ways in which they are processed. It has strengths in the unsupervised learning or discovery of structure in data, in pattern recognition, in the parsing and production of natural language, in several kinds of reasoning, and more. It lends itself to the analysis of streaming data, helping to overcome the problem of velocity in big data. Central in the workings of the system is lossless compression of information: making big data smaller and reducing problems of storage and management. There is potential for substantial economies in the transmission of data, for big cuts in the use of energy in computing, for faster processing, and for smaller and lighter computers. The system provides a handle on the problem of veracity in big data, with potential to assist in the management of errors and uncertainties in data. It lends itself to the visualisation of knowledge structures and inferential processes. A high-parallel, open-source version of the SP machine would provide a means for researchers everywhere to explore what can be done with the system and to create new versions of it.
